title: German (905) Weissenburg Gospel Illuminated Bible
description: The Weissenburg Gospel, produced between 863 and 871 by Otfried, a learned monk from Weissenburg (now Wissembourg, Alsace), represents a significant milestone in Old High German literature. Otfried, a student of Rabanus Maurus, innovatively introduced end rhyme into Old High German poetry through this work, which is essentially a metrical Gospel harmony drawing from all four Gospels to recount the life of Christ in the southern Rhine Franconian dialect. This manuscript, a counterpart to the Old Saxon Heliand, is divided into five books plus a prologue, showcasing the narrative in a harmonized form. Copied on 125 parchment leaves in 902‒5 in Freising by order of Bishop Waldo, the manuscript evidences the transition from Carolingian minuscule to the 10th-century script, with a unique column layout and red initials marking the beginning of odd-numbered lines. After disappearing during the secularization of Freising Cathedral Library in 1803, it was rediscovered a year later in the cathedral archives and subsequently transferred to the Munich Court Library, the precursor to today’s Bavarian State Library, preserving a key piece of Germanic Christian heritage and literary history.
